content: birch leaf shawl knitting lace triangle endless bottomup accessoires easy to work shawl based on a pretty leaf pattern with two different construction methods to choose from the pretty birch leaf pattern is an old standard in lace knitting and can easily be incorporated into a bottom-up or into a sideways shawl construction that way you won t risk running out of yarn having to cast on only a small amount of stitches in the beginning certainly counts as a bonus in my book this old time favorite lace pattern saw quite the boom with sharon miller s pattern birch originally published in rowan magazine no 34 2003 the original pattern is worked in a classic mohair yarn that gives it its lovely ethereal quality it comes with two major drawbacks though the first hurdle is casting on 300 stitches in slippery mohair yarn the second one pertains to the lack of charts as was usual for rowan for the longest time another issue seemed to lie with the required amount of yarn the 3 balls didn t seem enough for quite a few knitters buying a whole ball of yarn only to finish the last few row is at least annoying if not entirely impossible for example with discontinued yarns yarn this shawl can be worked in any type of yarn i find that the minimum amount of yarn to give a sizable finished shawl is about 400 meters shown in the pictures is a version in white hand spun lace yarn and a pink version in malabrigo lace needles choose needle size appropriate for your chosen yarn lace patterns are usually worked on needles at least 2 sizes larger than given on the ball band page 1 * birch leaf shawl © susan gutperl * susan@gutperl de notions if needed stitch markers to repeats and tapestry needle for weaving in ends instructions for construction a cast on 5 stitches purl across back and start working chart row 1 repeat row 9 to 16 as often as you like for every time these 8 row are repeated the part inside the dotted box gets worked one more time than before for construction b cast on 4 stitches purl across back and start working chart row 1 repeat row 25 to 40 as often as you like for every time these row are repeated the part inside the dotted box gets worked one more time i like knitting a chain selvedge because i think it looks clean and professional to do so slip the first stitch on every row and knit the last stitch on every row but of course you can treat the edge stitches any way you like the good thing about this pattern is you can stop any time just cast off loosely as soon as you re running out of yarn or when you think the shawl is large enough finishing weave in ends wash and block for the lace pattern to open up properly enjoy
